Gender dysphoria is like body dysmorphia in many ways I think. Someone with body dysmorphia isn #8217;t fat but they think they are and as a result will starve themselves. As this is dangerous because they may die, we don #8217;t allow this as a society and these people need to be treated, yet in most cases they will never lose their body dysmorphia. They will always think they are fat but will learn that they have to trust those around them and live in their body which they perceive to be fat. Gender dysphoria is the same. Let #8217;s take a biological female who wants to be a male. They see themselves as a male in the same way someone with gender dysphoria sees themselves as fat, but because it is safe to do so we allow them to transition. Gender dysphoria is a mental illness which is why it #8217;s hard for those without it to understand like it #8217;s hard for us to understand why someone with body dysmorphia can see themselves as fat when bones are clearly visible.

My friend #8217;s twin sister (aged 15) died two weeks ago of a rare disease and she copes mainly through the support of everyone else. Of course she died in a different way and before the final operation which she was unlikely to survive (and unfortunately didn #8217;t) everyone did say their goodbyes so it is different. She says being unable to call herself a twin or able to say she is a twin but her twin is no longer here is the hardest thing because being a twin is special and separated you from the crowd. Additionally, I was a twin but my twin had a still birth so I never knew until I was about 6yo but since then I have always felt partially responsible because I must have killed her in the womb or something but you need to learn it #8217;s not your fault and it will take time but you will be able to move on. Being slim isn #8217;t what is good for you. It #8217;s eating a balanced diet and having nothing in excess which results in one being slim. One can be slim and still eat #8216;unhealthy foods #8217; and that is not healthy as they will still have high cholesterol and other problems. Additionally, being slim through diet and exercise is what is good for you. Being slim because you take pills or whatever IS NOT GOOD FOR YOU. My brother #8217;s friend died from a weight loss pill and obviously that wouldn #8217;t be the ones they advertise but that #8217;s against the point. Bringing to light that these exist is the problem. One of my best friends has an eating disorder. She is slim. She is NOT healthy. Also health isn #8217;t only physical, I always the think the best test of one #8217;s health is if they are happy. Mental health is important too :)

Please read all of this. You are correct, we are an obese nation, but do you know why obesity is a problem? The physical size of an obese person is not the problem. The problem is that they have high cholesterol, low self esteem (of course not in all cases) and other health problems. I agree to some extent that extra weight may be problematic but that is not the main issue. Weight loss pills don #8217;t make anyone any more healthy. They do not reduce cholesterol levels, in fact in most cases they increase them as weight loss pills leave people feeling more hungry causing more eating. Despite what you may think immediately, weight loss pills also do not improve self esteem. Once comments start rolling in saying how good you look now people tend to become more self conscious as people are focussing on their appearance more. Additionally, people think appearance is more important than their true self. If we want to reduce the obesity rates why not start advertising a fitness class or a healthy alternative snack idea not something that is unhealthy, unnecessary and overall bad. My brother #8217;s friend died from a weight loss pill and it was adverts like these that told him they exist and he should take them. He wasn #8217;t obese or even remotely fat, we must remember everyone watches the same adverts. My friend has an eating disorder and stays 3 nights a week in a clinic. They all watch love island and have discussions about it in therapy but they can #8217;t watch the adverts because imagine what that could do to them! Think about all viewers before advertising! Also don #8217;t make comments that are over generalised. Thank you
